title: 110_hr3142
content:
The Act titled "Violent Crime Prevention and Enforcement Act of 2007" includes provisions for graduated penalties for civil violations by federal firearms licensees. The "Violent Crime Prevention and Enforcement Act of 2007" allows the Attorney General to impose civil money penalties or suspend licenses for violations by federal firearms licensees. Penalties can be up to $1,000 per violation or a maximum of $5,000 for violations from a single inspection. License suspension can last up to 30 days for willful violations. The Violent Crime Prevention and Enforcement Act of 2007 authorizes the Attorney General to impose penalties on federal firearms licensees for violations. Penalties can include civil money fines of up to $2,500 per violation or license suspension for up to 90 days for serious violations. Total penalties for violations from a single inspection cannot exceed $15,000. The Violent Crime Prevention and Enforcement Act of 2007 allows the Attorney General to impose penalties on federal firearms licensees for violations. Penalties can include civil money fines of up to $2,500 per violation, license suspension for up to 90 days, or license revocation. When determining the amount of a civil money penalty, factors such as the nature of the violation, the size of the firearms business, and the licensee's prior record are considered. Licensees can request the Attorney General to consider their ability to pay a penalty and submit relevant documents for review. The Violent Crime Prevention and Enforcement Act of 2007 allows the Attorney General to impose penalties on federal firearms licensees for violations. Penalties can include civil money fines of up to $15,000 for violations of minor and serious nature from a single inspection. The Attorney General may defer or suspend civil money penalties for licensees with suspended licenses. Regulations will determine violations considered serious. Enforcement actions cannot be initiated by the Attorney General. The Attorney General has a 2-year limit to enforce violations and can introduce evidence of willfulness. Licensees must be notified 30 days before any penalty is imposed, with the option to request a hearing to review the determination or denial. Licensees have 30 days to request a hearing to review a determination or denial of a penalty. Licensees have 30 days to request a hearing to review a determination or denial of a penalty. Changes include updating language related to license revocation to now refer to imposing sanctions under subsection (e) instead. The amendments made by this section will take effect 270 days after the enactment of the Act, updating language related to license revocation to now refer to imposing sanctions under subsection (e). SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS RELATING TO VIOLENT CRIME. Amendment to section 924(h) of title 18, United States Code, increases penalty for knowingly transferring a firearm for use in a crime of violence or drug trafficking to a maximum of 20 years imprisonment. Amendment to section 371 of title 18 increases conspiracy penalty to 20 years, or the maximum penalty for the crime involved in the conspiracy, whichever is less. The penalty for conspiracy offenses can be up to 20 years imprisonment or the maximum penalty for the crime involved. Possession of firearms by dangerous felons is addressed in Section 4. Section 924(e) of title 18, United States Code is amended to increase penalties for individuals who violate section 922(g) by possessing firearms after previous convictions for violent felonies or serious drug offenses. Penalties include up to 15 years imprisonment, fines, or both, depending on the number of prior convictions and elapsed time since release. The amendment to section 924(e) of title 18, United States Code increases penalties for individuals violating section 922(g) by possessing firearms after previous convictions. Penalties include up to 20 years imprisonment, fines, or both, with stricter penalties for multiple prior convictions. The United States Sentencing Commission will adjust the Federal Sentencing Guidelines accordingly. The amendment increases penalties for violations of section 922(g) of title 18, United States Code, in accordance with section 924(e) of that title. SEC. 5 amends Section 3142(e) of title 18, US Code to expand the rebuttable presumption against releasing persons charged with firearms offenses. SEC. 6 makes a conforming amendment to Section 922(d) by adding "transfer" after "sell." SEC. 7 increases penalties for interstate and foreign travel or transportation in aid of racketeering. Section 1952 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include harsher punishments for performing or attempting certain acts, with fines and imprisonment up to 20 years for some violations and potential life imprisonment or death penalty for others. SEC. 8. INCREASED PENALTIES FOR USE OF INTERSTATE COMMERCE FACILITIES IN THE COMMISSION OF MURDER-FOR-HIRE AND OTHER FELONY CRIMES OF VIOLENCE. Section 1958 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include the use of interstate commerce facilities in the commission of murder-for-hire and other felony crimes of violence. The amendment specifies that individuals involved in such crimes may face death or life imprisonment if death results, or if the crime is kidnapping or aggravated. Section 1958 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include penalties for various crimes of violence. These penalties range from imprisonment for any term of years or life for certain crimes like kidnapping or maiming, to not more than 20 years for other cases. The amendment also updates the item relating to section 1958 in the table of sections. SEC. 9. STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS FOR VIOLENT CRIME.

    Amends Chapter 213 of title 18, United States Code to include a new section, Sec. 3299A, which sets a 10-year statute of limitations for prosecuting noncapital felony crimes of violence, racketeering activities, or gang crimes involving violence. SEC. 10. STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS FOR TERRORISM OFFENSES is amended to extend the statute of limitations from 8 years to 10 years. SEC. 11. CRIMES OF VIOLENCE AND DRUG CRIMES COMMITTED BY ILLEGAL ALIENS introduces a new chapter 52 in title 18, United States Code for illegal aliens committing crimes of violence and drug offenses. Enhanced penalties for certain crimes committed by illegal aliens include fines, imprisonment up to 20 years for felony crimes of violence or drug trafficking. If the defendant was previously ordered removed for committing a crime, the penalty increases to imprisonment up to 30 years. Enhanced penalties for certain crimes committed by illegal aliens include fines and imprisonment up to 30 years. The term of imprisonment for an offense under this section cannot run concurrently with any other sentence. Enhanced penalties for certain crimes committed by illegal aliens include fines and imprisonment up to 30 years.
